required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Nurse-Family Partnership Impact Evaluation in South Carolina
clinical_study.official_title: Nurse-Family Partnership Impact Evaluation in South Carolina

collaborator.agency: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab
Katherine Baicker, University of Chicago Harris School of Public Policy

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the effects of the Nurse Family Partnership (NFP), an established home-visiting program, using a scientifically rigorous individual-level randomized controlled trial. The study will be based in South Carolina, where a Medicaid waiver in combination with a pay-for-success contract will allow expansion of the program to women on Medicaid. The study plans to enroll 4000 low-income, first time mothers and their children into the intervention group, and another 2000 into the control group. The study will evaluate the program's impacts on outcomes using administrative records. This study aims to yield new evidence on the effect of NFP in a modern context, applied to a new population, across a broad range of outcomes, and financed by a novel public-private partnership based on accountability for outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study is an individual-level randomized controlled trial, with randomization post-consent. The study will enroll pregnant women who are income-eligible for Medicaid, less than 28 weeks pregnant, and have not had a previous live birth. All eligible applicants who provide written consent will be randomly assigned either to a treatment group that is offered access to NFP or to a control group that is not. Two-thirds of those recruited will be randomized to the treatment group and one-third to the control group. Control group members will have access to the standard of care and whatever other programs and services are available in the community.
The investigators will assess the effect of NFP on a range of short- and long-run maternal and child outcomes using administrative data that will be available for all members of both treatment and control groups. Several of the outcomes the investigators will evaluate are required as part of the Medicaid waiver and pay-for-success financing model.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The Nurse-Family Partnership (NFP) was launched by pediatrician David Olds in the early 1970s in response to the observation that low-income mothers are less likely to engage in positive health and parenting behaviors that are associated with better child development outcomes (Olds et al. 1986). NFP is a prenatal and infancy home visiting program for low-income, first-time mothers and their families. Registered nurses begin visiting their clients as early in the pregnancy as possible, helping the mother-to-be make informed choices. The nurses continue visiting regularly until the child is two years old.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificates between first birth and potential second birth at time of birth(s). Participants will be followed for at least two years after the first birth
primary_outcome.description: Number of months from the birth of the first child until the subsequent birth

primary_outcome.time_frame: Captured in all-payer discharge data within 24 months post-partum
primary_outcome.description: Fraction of infants with emergency department visits and hospitalizations within 24 months post-partum

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born at less than 37 weeks

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born at less than 32 weeks

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born at less than 28 weeks

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born with a birth weight of less than 2500 grams

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured in all-payer discharge data over length of NICU stay within three months post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants admitted to the NICU

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured in all-payer discharge data over length of NICU stay within three months post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Number of days an infants stay in NICU before discharge

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificates within 24 months post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of subsequent infants born within 24 months after the first birth

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificates within 18 months post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of subsequent infants birth within 18 months after the first birth

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants born via different delivery methods (e.g. c-section)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers with any tobacco use during their pregnancy

secondary_outcome.measure: Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC) use in 3 days after birth
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured in all-payer discharge data within a three day post-partum period
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers with any LARC use (implant or intrauterine device insertion) within three days after birth

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate and National Death Index provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention within 28 days post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants that die under 28 days of age

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate and National Death Index provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention within one year post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants that die under one year of age

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate and National Death Index provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention within five years post-partum
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants that die under five years of age

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers who exceed recommended pregnancy weight gain

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured in all-payer discharge data at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of infants stillborn

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers diagnosed with diabetes during pregnancy

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers diagnosed with hypertension during pregnancy

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Captured by Vital Records Birth Certificate at birth
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of mothers diagnosed with preeclampsia during pregnancy

arm_group.description: NFP is a prenatal and infancy home visiting program for low-income, first-time mothers and their families. Registered nurses begin visiting their clients as early in the pregnancy as possible, helping the mother-to-be make informed choices. The nurses continue visiting regularly until the child is two years old.
Control group members have access to the standard of care and whatever other programs and services are available in the community.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female
- No previous live births
- Currently pregnant
- Gestation period less than 28 weeks (i.e. less than or equal to 27 weeks, 6 days) at time of recruitment
- Ages 15-55
- Income level meets Medicaid eligibility criteria
- Live within an area serviced by a NFP Implementing Agency
- Not currently enrolled in the study
- Not incarcerated or living in lock down facilities
Exclusion Criteria:
- Men
- Women who have had a previous live birth
- Women who are not currently pregnant
- Women who are past their 28th week of gestation (i.e. greater than or equal to 28 weeks, 0 days) at time of recruitment
- Women who are younger than 15 or older than 55 years of age
- Women whose income level does not meet Medicaid eligibility criteria
- Women who live outside of an area serviced by a NFP Implementing Agency
- Women who are currently enrolled in the study
- Women who are currently incarcerated or living in a lock down facility

facility.name: Family Solutions of the Lowcountry NFP

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Global Health Economics
